title: Choppy markets send broker Panmure to a loss
text:

Tue, Sep 29, 2015, 11:56 BST - UK Markets close in 4 hrs 34 mins Choppy markets send broker Panmure to a loss By Marion Dakers | Telegraph – 6 minutes ago 0.000 
Stockbroker is finding it tough to bring the queue of companies to market 
A drought of big deals during the general election and months of volatile world markets have swung stockbroker Panmure Gordon into a half-year loss. 
The City of London firm lost £200,000 before tax in the first half of the year, compared with a £2m profit in the same period of 2014. 
The broker’s net commission and fee income slumped by a fifth to £13.1m, with cautious investors only agreeing to buy into small share sales while the markets struggled to digest an uncertain election in the UK, the fallout from Greece’s debt negotiations and turbulence from China's seesawing stocks and shares. 
“I would love to think that it’s stabilised and to correct that lack of deals, but look at the markets today, with Asia down and commodity prices where they are,” said Phillip Wale, chief executive. “It’s making it difficult to execute what is a strong pipeline of IPOs.” 
Fewer firms have taken the plunge with an initial public offering this year. London has hosted 29 floats on the main market so far this year, compared to 39 at the same stage of 2014, according to Thomson Reuters (Dusseldorf: TOC.DU - news ) data through to September 18. 
Panmure doubled its spending on redundancies to £376,000, although the overall headcount has risen from 118 after a deal to take over Charles Stanley (LSE: CAY.L - news ) ’s securities division in July. 
The 139-year-old company won the race to buy the firm for up to £6.5m, depending on performance, and has said the acquisition will grant the company greater access to merger and acquisition work and bond broking. 
The group, which brought in the Qatari bank QInvest as a major investor in 2009, restored its dividend in March this year for the first time since the financial crisis. 
Mr Wale said the firm's major investors have "had nothing but sympathy for the state of the market". Aim-listed shares in Panmure, which are scarcely-traded and therefore volatile, fell 20pc to 98.5p in early trading, the lowest price since a share consolidation in early 2013.
